The text covers various aspects of cucumbers, including their description, varieties, cultivation history, nutritional information, and uses in culinary practices, as well as global production statistics, with China being the leading producer.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides detailed information about cucumbers, including their classification, description, nutritional value, varieties, uses, and cultivation history. Cucumbers are a widely-cultivated plant in the Cucurbitaceae family, known for their cylindrical fruits used as culinary vegetables, with origins in Asia but now grown worldwide. The article also covers the genetic aspects, pollination, historical cultivation, and production statistics, emphasizing cucumbers' global significance and diversity.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mizeria: Mizeria is a traditional Polish salad made primarily of thinly sliced cucumbers and sour cream, with variations including ingredients like onions, dill, and lemon juice. It is commonly served as a side dish and its name, deriving from the French word for "misery," reflects the Polish aristocracy's contempt for this peasant food.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#G: The content provides an extensive overview of cucumbers (Cucumis sativus), detailing their cultivation history, biological characteristics, nutritional information, varieties, uses, and global production statistics. Cucumbers are a widely-cultivated vine plant in the Cucurbitaceae family, known for their cylindrical fruits used in culinary contexts, with origins in Asia and a rich history of cultivation dating back at least 3,000 years.
https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?tit: The content provides a comprehensive overview of cucumbers (_Cucumis sativus_), detailing their classification, cultivation, varieties, nutritional information, uses, and production statistics. Originating in Asia and now cultivated worldwide, cucumbers are classified into three main types—slicing, pickling, and seedless/burpless—and are used both culinarily and in pickling. China leads global production, emphasizing the cucumber's significance in international agriculture and cuisine.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitter_(ta: The gustatory system, responsible for the sense of taste, involves the perception of taste (flavor) through a complex process that begins when substances in the mouth react chemically with taste receptor cells located on taste buds. These receptors detect the five basic tastes: sweetness, sourness, saltiness, bitterness, and umami (savoriness), with each taste contributing to the overall flavor of food in combination with senses like smell, texture, and temperature. Taste perception varies among individuals due to factors like genetics and age, influencing dietary preferences and nutritional health.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potassium_: The content provides a detailed overview of the biological importance of potassium, including its roles in maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance, enabling nerve function, and supporting plant growth. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxonomy_(: This comprehensive text outlines the structure and content related to the scientific discipline of taxonomy within biology, focusing on the classification, naming, and defining of organisms based on shared characteristics. The text also mentions key figures and milestones in the development of taxonomy, such as Carl Linnaeus, and discusses the impact of modern technologies like DNA sequencing on the field.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides a detailed overview of cucumbers (Cucumis sativus), focusing on their classification, cultivation history, varieties, nutritional information, and uses. It explains that cucumbers are widely-cultivated creeping vine plants belonging to the Cucurbitaceae family, used primarily as culinary vegetables. Originating in Asia, cucumbers have been domesticated for over 3,000 years, with numerous cultivars developed for slicing, pickling, and seedless consumption. The article also covers cucumber production, highlighting China as the leading producer, and includes various sections on cucumber's botanical aspects, pollination mechanisms, and defense against herbivores.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Ra: Saint-Bernard-de-Lacolle is a municipality in Quebec, Canada, in the Les Jardins-de-Napierville Regional County Municipality of the Montérégie administrative area, established in 1855, with a population of 1,542 as per the 2021 census. It features a major border crossing with the United States at Champlain, New York, and has a history of population changes reflected in census data, with French recognized as its official language for both formal and informal use.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucurbitac: The content provides an overview of the Cucurbitaceae family, also known as the gourd family, which includes about 965 species across 101 genera, with significant ones being squash, pumpkin, watermelon, cucumber, and melons. It details the family's classification, fossil history, description, and pests and diseases, alongside referencing scientific studies and further reading on the subject.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides detailed information about cucumbers (_Cucumis sativus_), a widely-cultivated plant that produces cylindrical fruits primarily used as vegetables. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tendrils: Tendrils are specialized plant organs used by climbing plants for support and attachment, evolving from stems, leaves, or petioles, and vary in their biological and morphological origins across different species. Charles Darwin’s studies highlighted their movement and coiling mechanisms, emphasizing their role in climbing and the evolutionary advantage of reaching sunlight by supporting themselves on structures or other plants.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldehyde: The content provides a comprehensive overview of aldehydes, a class of organic compounds containing a functional group with the structure R−CH=O, covering their structure, bonding, physical properties, methods of synthesis, common reactions, and applications. It also details the occurrence of aldehydes in nature, their industrial significance, various methods for their identification, and their role in biochemistry, along with providing examples of aldehydes and dialdehydes, and explaining the nomenclature rules for naming aldehydes according to IUPAC standards.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: This content provides an extensive overview of cucumbers (_Cucumis sativus_), detailing their cultivation, varieties, nutritional value, culinary uses, and production statistics. Originating in Asia and cultivated for at least 3,000 years, cucumbers are classified into slicing, pickling, and seedless types, with China leading global production. The text also touches on their botanical characteristics, including their growth as creeping vines, flowering and pollination processes, and defense mechanisms against herbivores.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Moun: The Rocky Mountains, also known as the Rockies, are a significant mountain range stretching over 3,000 miles from British Columbia in Canada to New Mexico in the United States, making them the largest mountain system in North America. They formed from 80 to 55 million years ago during the Laramide orogeny and feature a diverse range of ecosystems, from arid desert to alpine tundra, hosting a variety of flora and fauna. The Rockies are also a major tourist destination, offering activities such as hiking, skiing, and camping, and are rich in natural resources like minerals and coalbed methane.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollenizer: A pollenizer, often confused with a pollinator, is a plant that provides pollen for the fertilization of other plants, playing a crucial role in pollination management by offering abundant, compatible, and viable pollen during the same flowering period as the pollinated plant. This term is specifically used to distinguish from pollinators, which are the agents, like bees and birds, that physically transfer the pollen.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:: This content provides a detailed guide on the use and application of the "Citation needed" tag within Wikipedia articles, explaining when and how to use it, alternatives to its use, and guidance for editors whose work has been tagged. It also outlines ways to help reduce the backlog of articles with unsourced statements, emphasizing the importance of verifiability and the collaborative nature of editing on Wikipedia.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peel_(frui: The content describes the peel (also known as rind or skin) of fruits and vegetables, highlighting its nutritional value, uses, and differences in edibility across various types of fruits. It emphasizes the nutritional benefits of orange peel, including its rich content in dietary fiber and vitamin C, and discusses how peels can be used in cooking, such as for making zest, marmalade, or as a garnish in cocktails.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missouri_B: The Missouri Botanical Garden, located in St. Louis, Missouri, and founded in 1859 by Henry Shaw, is a National Historic Landmark and one of the oldest botanical institutions in the U.S. It features a vast herbarium with over 6.6 million specimens, making it the second largest in North America, and offers a range of horticultural displays, research facilities, and educational programs across its 79-acre site, including a Japanese strolling garden, the Climatron conservatory, and various cultural festivals.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_C: This comprehensive summary provides detailed information about Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, a vital nutrient found in citrus fruits and other foods, and essential for tissue repair, collagen formation, and immune system function. It outlines Vitamin C's history, dietary sources, recommended intake levels, medical uses, and potential adverse effects. Highlighting its role in preventing scurvy, the summary also touches on ongoing research into its benefits for skin aging, cancer, and its controversial use in megadosage treatments. Vitamin C's synthesis, both natural and industrial, and its significance in human nutrition and health are thoroughly examined, showcasing its multifaceted importance.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides a detailed overview of cucumbers (_Cucumis sativus_), a widely-cultivated plant that produces cylindrical fruits used as vegetables, with origins in Asia but now grown worldwide. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARKive: ARKive was a digital archive launched in 2003, aimed at conserving audiovisual records of the world's threatened species, especially those on the IUCN Red List, through collaboration with various conservation organizations, broadcasters, and academic institutions. Despite its significant contributions and recognitions, including being named the _Sunday Times_ website of the year in 2005, it was closed in February 2019 due to funding issues, with its extensive collection of over 100,000 images and videos stored offline for future generations.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manganese#: The content provides a comprehensive overview of the chemical element manganese, including its characteristics, isotopes, history, occurrence, production, and applications in industries such as steelmaking and aluminum alloys. Manganese is essential in various biological processes and human nutrition but can be toxic in excessive amounts.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides a comprehensive overview of cucumbers (Cucumis sativus), detailing their classification, cultivation history, varieties, uses in culinary contexts, production statistics, and nutritional information. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soilless_g: This extensive content details the principles and practices of hydroponics, a method of growing plants without soil by using mineral nutrient solutions in a water solvent. It covers various hydroponic techniques such as aeroponics, deep water culture, and nutrient film technique, as well as substrates like rock wool and coconut coir. Additionally, it discusses the history of hydroponics, nutrient solution formulations, and potential improvements such as CO2 enrichment and sophisticated growrooms to enhance plant growth and yield.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observatio: Observation.org is a global platform that supports naturalists, citizen scientists, and biologists in collecting, validating, and sharing biodiversity observations, accessible via its website or mobile apps like ObsIdentify. With a database of 233 million nature observations and 79 million photos, it operates under Dutch and European law by the non-profit foundation Observation International.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonne: The content provides an overview of the tonne (or metric ton), a unit of mass equivalent to 1,000 kilograms or 1 megagram, accepted for use with the International System of Units (SI). It elaborates on the symbol, origin, spelling, conversions, derived units, and alternative usages of the tonne, including its application in expressing energy equivalents like TNT and oil, and its historical context as both a unit of mass and (obsolete) force.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foraging: The content outlines the structure and main features of Wikipedia's article on foraging, including sections on factors influencing foraging behavior, types of foraging, and the ecological and genetic aspects that affect foraging strategies in animals. It also includes a comprehensive list of references, external links, and a detailed examination of solitary and group foraging behaviors, the impact of predators, parasitism, and environmental interactions on foraging, as well as the application of optimal foraging theory and foraging arena theory.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome: The article provides a comprehensive overview of genomes, covering their origins, definitions, components (including nuclear and organelle genomes), and the processes of sequencing and mapping. It discusses the diversity of genomes across viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes, including the human genome project and advancements in sequencing technology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_damage: The text provides a detailed overview of DNA damage, its types, frequencies, repair mechanisms, and implications for aging and cancer. DNA damage can result from both endogenous processes and environmental factors, leading to various biological consequences, including mutations and epigenetic alterations. The document also discusses the cellular response to DNA damage, including repair pathways and the role of apoptosis in preventing cancer. DNA damage is a significant concern for life, prompting extensive repair mechanisms across all cellular organisms to maintain genomic integrity.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encyclop%C: The Encyclopædia Britannica, a comprehensive English-language encyclopedia, has transitioned from print to exclusively online publication. Originating in 1768 in Edinburgh, Scotland, it grew in size and reputation, with its last printed edition in 2010. The encyclopedia is known for its scholarly content, contributed by many expert authors including Nobel laureates, and covers a wide range of topics across its editions.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S2CID_(ide: Semantic Scholar is a free AI-powered research tool developed by the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, launched in November 2015, for searching scientific literature, offering features like automatically generated paper summaries, and a corpus that includes over 200 million publications from all fields of science as of September 2022. It uses advanced natural language processing and machine learning techniques to help scholars quickly find relevant papers, understand their key points, and stay up to date with the latest research.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grocery_st: The content outlines the structure and navigation of a Wikipedia page on grocery stores, detailing various aspects such as definitions in different countries, history, types (including small and large format stores, and electronic options), regional variations, food marketing, and food waste, along with references, further reading, and external links. Grocery stores, known in different regions by various names, are retail stores primarily selling food and household supplies, with their definitions, history, and operational types varying globally.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echinocyst: The content provides detailed information about _Echinocystis_, a monotypic genus within the gourd family, Cucurbitaceae, specifically highlighting its sole species _Echinocystis lobata_ (wild cucumber). It covers various aspects including description, distribution, insect interactions, bacterial infection, and uses, alongside referencing its conservation status, scientific classification, and additional resources on Wikimedia Commons and Wikispecies.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber#c: The content provides a detailed overview of cucumbers, describing them as a widely-cultivated vine plant in the Cucurbitaceae family, known for their edible fruits used as culinary vegetables. Originating from Asia, cucumbers have three main types—slicing, pickling, and seedless—with a history of cultivation dating back at least 3,000 years, and have been genetically and culturally significant across various civilizations, including their development and trade globally.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepo_(bota: The content provides an overview of the botanical definition and classification of berries, detailing their characteristics, types, and uses. It explains that botanically, a berry is a fleshy fruit produced from a single flower with a single ovary, including fruits like grapes, tomatoes, and bananas, but excluding strawberries and raspberries which are not true berries in the botanical sense. The article further explores the various types of berry-like fruits, their culinary uses, historical significance, and commercial production, emphasizing the differences between botanical and culinary definitions of berries.
